author: hendrix_srv
body:
Every Balmer acquisition was written off as worthless.  Had they chosen someone other than Nadella to replace Balmer, MSFT might be with IBM.

I have a database that tracks revenues of many companies back to 2000, and I can select any group of companies and plot the revenue chart.  My "tech majors" groups is an astounding chart, with AAPL coming from the bottom and charting a steep course to the top in 05-10, and IBM and ORCL climbing early on then arcing back into the basement.

author: Rymasq
body:
people who said Tesla is an "AI" company probably don't work in tech. To put it bluntly, they are stupid. They don't even know what AI really is and that it is now everywhere, every company is technically an "AI" company. 

Now if Tesla has a substantially large amount of data on self driving, larger than any competitors, that is an asset that Tesla can absolutely sell. Until everyone else has that data, then the asset is worthless. 

One thing that history has proven though is that getting somewhere first doesn't necessarily mean making the most amount of money. A great example of this is MySpace who was then usurped by Facebook a few years later. Those Wright brothers sure did make a ton of money by discovering flight..right? E.F Codd invented the relational database at IBM but Oracle sure does make a TON more money off it today.

author: Unlucky-Prize
body:
I asked the oracle about china, we should be good:

[https://imgur.com/a/eFoLBuu](https://imgur.com/a/eFoLBuu)

&#x200B;

full text:

"Tomorrow the massive evergrande debt crisis in china will be resolved. This is because the renminbi is a hard currency, and China has very few competitors for the renminbi. So its very unlikely that they will be under pressure to devalue the renminbi against the dollar, given that the renminbi is a stable currency. It would be hard for the US to make a move on China by saying that they can no longer have imports in dollars, as China is the #1 consumer of US imports.  
The only possible crisis in the next 24 hours is that Chinese companies might try to borrow in dollars, because they cant really borrow in renminbi. Its not that the renminbi is not a hard currency, its just that there is a lot of liquidity in the Chinese market, and banks could borrow in any currency they want. But since the Chinese government has been very careful in the past not to print money to finance bad assets, they will only go with renminbi."

author: Potado
body: Bloomberg Terminals are becoming VERY dated. They were and still are the industry standard, but they're in the class of commercial tech products that really let themselves go after gaining monopolistic notoriety pre-2000. The Oracle database is another example - developers haven't done shit on that product for decades despite it continuing to power many huge enterprise clients.

author: jessejerkoff
body:
I can tell you **exactly** why best buy is not the value play of the year. McKinsey even did a case study on them! The modernised their business on 2012, and think that is what customers want now. The main issue is What is good enough for the 2010s is ancient in the 2021 digital world.


What they did is ***de-dinosaur*** their business. Not digitally transform it.

Give it three years, best buy will have to do a digital transformation to survive into 2030. If they do it, then I'll buy in. Else they will fall.

You probably think one digital transformation is enough! And a revamped renew blue is all set up. You're wrong.

Microsoft had a similar problem, and so did SAP and Oracle.

Just because they are tech companies does not mean they are ready for the future. 

And just because best buy has a web site does not make them an e-commerce company.

author: kiwifruta
body:
The migration to Snowflake is taking much longer than initially anticipated. But the Snowflake SQL dialect is very similar to Oracle’s so it won’t take much to translate the SQL code and move the developers and analysts to a new dialect. 

Performance improvements with Snowflake were incredible. I heard ex-Oracle developers who held half their patents founded Snowflake so there is also an innovation loss for Oracle.

author: TackleMySpackle
body:
Personally, I only trade strangles when there is a known event coming. For example, with AFRM, I bought the ATM strangle (I think it was $95) about an hour before close of business on earnings day. 

I knew there would be a catalyst one way or the other within the next hour and that the next morning the price would swing likely in the positive direction. It did and I was successful.

With Nike, I jumped in a few days early thinking I would beat some of the IV. I was correct on that, but I guess a lot of other people did the same and that drove the price up $5 more than my strikes. When it crashed, the puts just didn't cover enough and I never adjusted - I should be flayed at the stake. 

I also bought Oracle ATM the day of (I think the morning of), and it dumped after earnings. I cashed the put out at about a 25% profit, but kept the call, because ORCL has a history of pumping a few weeks after earnings for their dividend. As of today, that call is now up about 10% so I went green on both sides of the straddle. I highly suggest you look at how ORCL performed a few weeks ago compared to last earnings. The chart patterns are almost identical. 

Each play is unique, but if you straddle just "under the suspicion" that the price will swing, without any assured date or event that might unfold, you might get lopsided.

One good rule of thumb I like is that a perfectly balanced straddle should find the put and call prices almost identical. Take CCXI, for example. If you bought the $17.50 straddle last week, the underlying has now moved up to $20. The $17.50C Nov is now worth more than the $17.50P Nov (for obvious reasons). If you wanted to balance this, you'd be better off rolling your put to the $20 because the pricing of the two is almost equivalent. It wouldn't technically be a straddle at that point, but you probably smell what I'm stepping in. 

Of course, if you find yourself rolling to the next higher strike, you're not really doing yourself any favors either, but I'm just trying to point out the balance aspect here. 

One other note with straddles: IV can fuck you. CCXI is, I believe, the highest IV stock right now. If you straddled it now just in case the FDA approval doesn't go through, you might get IV crushed while your calls evaporate. In which case, you're not really reaping the benefit of the straddle. If you do CCXI, your best bet is to either sell puts and collect fat premiums and hope it skyrockets, or buy calls and hope it skyrockets. Buying puts right now, IMO, is not smart, but definitely track it so you can see how it would have unfolded for you. That's the best thing to do.

TLDR: Buy an ATM straddle with about 45-60 DTE  just before an event; hopefully before IV gets nuts. Expect one side of your straddle to be sacrificial, but don't sell it if it does die. Milk the call/put that does perform for everything it's worth. Then, hang on to the dead side in hopes of a retraction/bounce in the other direction. Try to collect on both ends of the straddle.

author: Free-Author
body:
Dustin Moskovitz visited me in a dream last night, telling me I was getting cocky as I was still holding my ASAN calls from pre-earnings and looking to dump some to play SMAR today.  Things were going down, so I sold my ASAN calls and decided to get humble on American in general, buying some puts and Oracle calls and SMAR calls, anyway.

ASAN turned around.  Even though I'd be up 50% had I held it from where I am now, I am glad I got out with a big gain since ASAN was a yolo, and I didn't have much, left.  Riding the trend makes a profit, so here is to riding the downward SPY trend!
